Authors:
Wilawan Kuephadungphan, Kanoksri Tasanathai, Booppa
Petcharad, Artit Khonsanit, Marc Stadler, Janet Jennifer
Luangsa-ard
Title:
Phylogeny- and morphology-based recognition of new species in
spider-parasitic fungus Gibellula from Thailand
Keywords:
Cordycipitaceae; spider specialist fungus; taxonomy; 4 new
taxa
Abstract:
Thailand is known to be a part of what is called the
Indo-Burma biodiversity hotspot, hosting the vast array of living
organisms across its diverse ecosystems. This is reflected in an
increasing number of species described over time, especially fungi.
Despite these facts, a very limited number of species in specialized
spider-parasitic Gibellula has ever been reported from the country. A
survey of invertebrate-pathogenic fungi in Thailand for several decades
has enabled us to find a number of fungal specimens with affinities to
the genus. Integrating morphological traits into multi-locus
phylogenetic analysis uncovered four new species consisting of G.
pigmentosinum, G. cebrennini, G. fusiformispora and G. scorpioides. All
these appeared to be exclusively linked with torrubiella-like sexual
morphs with the presence of Granulomanus asexual morph in G.
pigmentosinum and G. cebrennini. In addition to these, our current study
remarkably exhibited high host specificity of these new species towards
their spider hosts and revealed the evidence of manipulation of host
behavior in G. scorpioides for the first time.
